characters: AN AUDIENCE, AND HE DOESN'T QUITE KNOW WHAT TO DO WITH HI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outrageous flashing lights sparkle in the reflection of t windshield of a 2003 Subaru station wagon. Slumped behind wheel is GERRY KARTWELL (early-40s, mustached). He listen Joe Navarro’s audio book of “200 Poker Tells” on CD. JOE NAVARRO’S VOICE Ninety-eight. Furrowing of Forehead. Furrowing of the forehead is a good indicator that something is amiss or the person is insecure. It is also seen when people are concentrating or trying to make sense of something. CLOSE ON Gerry, glassy-eyed, perhaps fighting back tears. JOE NAVARRO’S VOICE (CONT’D) It is usually associated with doubt, weakness, or concern. Gerry looks in his rearview mirror, contorts and relaxes face in a tension-releasing exercise. He does this severa times, until he’s ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are behind the shaggy hair of a bearded man. He brushe teeth, leans over the sink and spits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry steps through the entrance, nods to the SECURITY GU who smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Hey Gerry. Good luck tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still from behind, we see the bearded man apply deodorant his shirt, then tuck the stick back into his leather duff

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry enters the casino’s poker room, steps up to the CAS hands over his player’s card and sixty bucks.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Hey Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hey Louise. How’s the knee?  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 2.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: It’s gettin’ there. She hands him a printed ticket.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good luck. He glances at his ticket and wanders over to his assigned where he joins several players awaiting the start of toni low-stakes tournament.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (to the dealer) Hey Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Whatta ya say there, Gerry? Gerry nods and Chuck slides over a stack of chips. Also seated at the table are-- CLIFFORD HOUSTON (40s, wea visor and goatee, with a permanent cranky scowl). WILL (20s, wearing a hoodie and sunglasses, listening to “BLOODY MARY” KATE (60s, drinking a bloody mary). LARRY (30s, black, laid back). Gerry folds his cards for the first several hands. There calm, casual banter at the table.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Anyone know the spread on the Hawkeyes game?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Six points.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: Gettin’ hot out there.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It’s just weather.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: What does that mean, “It’s just weather?”

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hot, cold... it’s just weather, baby.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 3.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I like that. “It’s just weather, baby.” Gerry and the others laugh. Meanwhile, Clifford has been raising Larry, and they reve their cards. Clifford wins and reels in his chips.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, it’s just poker, baby. How’s that? You like that one? We ZOOM past Gerry at the table to reveal the bearded dri approaching in the background. This man is CURTIS VONN (30s, handsome with a devil-may-c attitude). We reverse ZOOM back to Gerry at the table, wh the conversation continues...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Anyone see that rainbow yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: Missed it.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I drove to the end of a rainbow once.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Wasn't nothin’ there. Just faded out into the trees. Curtis has now arrived at Gerry’s table, pulls out a chai

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Table seven looks like heaven. How is everybody feeling tonight? Not sure what to make of this guy, most folks just nod.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: (passing him chips) Have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What’s the word, people?  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 4.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: It’s just poker, baby.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Hey, it’s okay with me. lLet’s play some cards. Chuck dishes out the next hand; everyone peeks at their c

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aces are good, right? Curtis smiles, bets a stack of chips. Most players fold. Gerry. He raises. Without missing a beat, Curtis meets Ge raise. When the flop comes down with an Ace, the one other remai player folds. But Gerry looks quietly at the still-smilin Curtis and calls bullshit, raising him once again. Curtis looks Gerry over, zeroing in on a MISSING BUTTON O GERRY'S SHIRT. (It’s an odd detail to focus on in a momen this, but that’s the kind of guy Curtis is.) He mucks his cards, and Gerry reels in the pot.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: Aces, huh?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Why would I fold Aces? MINUTES LATER. A waitress comes by.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Anyone need any drinks?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Bloody Mary.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What is the bourbon?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Just the cheap stuff.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Make mine a Woodford.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: I’ll have to check if we have--  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 5.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (to Gerry) --Hey friend, you want a Woodford?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: The cheap stuff is fine with me.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Bring him a Woodford, too.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: That’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, it’s on me. Gerry nods thanks. The friendly banter continues over mul hands...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What’s the bad beat jackpot at?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Ninety five.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: When's the last time it hit?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Long time.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I got a bad beat jackpot story... My old buddy, Tony Roundtree-- anyone know Tony? Blank looks and head shakes.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hosts a high rollers game every other month in New Orleans now. But I knew him when he was up in Detroit.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You from Detroit? The bet comes around to Curtis, who nonchalantly bets a l stack of chips. The next two players fold.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Me? I’m from all over, but I knew Tony Roundtree up in Detroit. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He loved to play poker, but he kept dodging my invitations to play in the casinos. Story goes like this... ON GERRY scrutinizing Curtis for a tell... CLOSE ON CURTIS’ details as he continues with the story: gestures, smile, hazel eyes... he shows no signs of stres Gerry folds his hand, and Curtis rakes in the pot.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Apparently Tony had a little bit of a gambling problem before I met him. You guys know about the disassociated persons list? Not sure you have it in Iowa. But some states you can put yourself on this list if you’re trying to quit gambling. Which means you are legally banned from all casinos in the state.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: For life.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: For life. So you know what I’m talking about. It makes sense, right? Well, not to Tony. He put himself on the list to show his girlfriend he was serious about changing his ways. Of course, a few months go by and she dumps him for a guitar player.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: It's always a guitar player.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It is always a guitar player, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Nice hands.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: So he’s lonely and depressed and gets the itch to play poker again. Walks to the MGM-- “Sorry buddy.” Greektown-- “no can do, amigo.” Motor City-- “no dice, pal.” So what does he do?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Disguise.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 7.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Yes! He puts on sunglasses, fake mustache-- a wig.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: C'mon, a wig?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’ve never been more serious. He makes it past security, takes a seat in the poker room, and he’s in heaven. What a rush that must have been. He’s finally back in action, and-- The waitress returns with a tray of drinks.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, they don’t have Woodford. Our top shelf is Bulleit. She sets the bourbon glasses in front of Curtis and Gerry

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Okay, fine... but I’m not paying for his.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I said his Woodford is on me. That is not a Woodford. Awkward beat. Curtis smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m only kidding... Keep the change, darlin’. Curtis takes a moment to enjoy the ritual of a toast. He his glass up to Gerry, who does the same.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good luck to you, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Thanks. They sip their drinks.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Better than the cheap shit, right? Gerry shrugs, nods politely.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 8.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: So what happened? Beat. Curtis transitions back into story mode.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: He’s at the table for a couple hours, playing the best poker of his life. Up four, five thousand, when some guy’s straight flush beats another guy’s four cowboys. Everyone at the table knows what this means and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Jackpot!

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Hundred fifty thousand dollar bad beat jackpot. To be split between all five players at the table.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: Thirty grand a piece.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Thirty grand a piece. Unless you happen to be a disassociated person who is breaking the law by just being in the room. So while everyone else is high-fiving and back-slapping, Tony jumps up, leaves his chips on the table, and makes a bee-line for the nearest exit... And he hasn’t stepped foot inside a casino since. Curtis sips his bourbon. Gerry smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: And what is the lesson here?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: The lesson? Lady, lighten up, it's just a story. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry enters the bar with a bounce to his step. A college basketball game plays on the TV. The bartender, DALE, gre him.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 9.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Hey Gerry, how’d it go tonight?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Placed third.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Congrats! What’s the payout on that?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Nine hundred. What’s the score here?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Not sure. Have a seat. Gerry straddles a bar stool, scans the TV screen for a sc

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Oregon up six. Okay. That’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: The usual for ya?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Uh... actually, do you have Woodford?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Let’s do one of those. Gerry keeps his eyes on the TV. A player misses a free th He winces.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: How much you got on this?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Nine hundred. Dale pours the Woodford and Gerry takes a sip, nods.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: It’s a Woodford kind of night.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: That guy over there shooting darts likes it too.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 10. We follow Gerry’s gaze over to the dart board, where Curt tosses a dart, shrugs, and pays his opponent five bucks. Gerry smiles, calls out to Curtis--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hey! Woodford man! Curtis looks over, recognizes Gerry. GERRY (CONT’D) Next one’s on me! Curtis (a little tipsy) steps over to the bar, sits next Gerry. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Name’s Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Curtis! Like Tony.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: More like Mayfield.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’m Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Like Lewis?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No. Just Gerry. With a G. Short for Gerald... Like Ford, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: How'd it go for you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What’s “not bad”?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Second.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Get outta here. That’s great.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Could have finished first if you didn’t bully me out of that mountain before you left.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 11.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Win some, lose some.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hey, where'd you disappear to anyway?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I can never last through those tournaments.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Then why’d you buy in?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I like people.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Well you should've stuck it out. You're a good player.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: For a few hours, maybe, but I don’t have the stamina for poker. I get restless.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: So what’s your game?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Darts.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You any good?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I can hit the board.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hey, I gotta ask... what were you holding? Curtis smiles, pauses for effect.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Pair a deuces. Gerry stares at him, always looking for the tell.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You asked.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 12.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: That’s all? No response. Is this guy for real?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can usually read people like a damn book. But you were all over the map my friend. I still can’t spot your tell.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You know why? Gerry waits for it.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t care about winning...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I just like to play. Curtis shrugs. Gerry watches him in wonder, then turns ba the TV.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see that rainbow yesterday? Gerry stares at Curtis. Is he serious?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yes! Amazing! It was fucking amazing!

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Best - rainbow - ever.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hey, why have I never seen you before?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m just passing through town.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Headed where?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: New Orleans.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I love New Orleans! You going to your friend’s high roller game?  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 13.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Tony Roundtree. Nah, I don’t have that kind of money.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: So, what then?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You’re just going down to New Orleans for the hell of it?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Pretty much.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Damn, that sounds alright.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It’s alright with me. LATER. Gerry and Curtis are hunched over the bar, drunk as hell, in the middle of describing a memorable poker hand.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I knew he had my two pair beat. But I also knew that he didn’t know he had me beat by the way he was betting. I had four or five already on the line, so I figure, what the hell, and I push the rest of my chips in. He sits there for five minutes. Just staring at me. So I say “Tell ya what. For fifty bucks, I‘1l show you one of my cards, whichever one you wanna see.” Curtis breaks into a smile.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: And whichever card you flip...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: ..-he thinks I got a full boat.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it really was. It was beautiful.  10 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 14. Beat. Gerry takes a quarter out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Twenty bucks... heads or tails?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Tails. Gerry flips the coin. It’s tails. He hands Curtis a twent

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Where did you come from?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m from a far away land where rainbows run free and whiskey grows on trees. ON GERRY for a bewildered beat. He almost believes him. LATER. Gerry and Curtis drunkenly play darts, missing the entirely, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry is passed out on the couch with a blanket draped ov Sun shines through the windows. The sound of silverware clinking stirs him awake. Gerry struggles to open his eyes, and sees a young woman, DENIS sitting down at the chair opposite him. She’s wearing paj and sprinkling Quik chocolate powder over a bowl of ice c she watches the morning news. Gerry looks around, struggling to remember where he is, w Curtis passes through the doorway in the bg and stops upo seeing Gerry. He’s naked, brushing his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (mouthful of toothpaste) Oh, good, you’re up.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You too.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Hey Denise, you got any coconut oil?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: I have lotion.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Nevermind. Curtis disappears into the bathroom.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 15.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Are you his, uh...?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Just friends.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Thanks for the couch.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: You want breakfast? Curtis returns in a pink robe.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Dog races start at one.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Nine-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I have work.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You have a job? Gerry nods, puts on his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Where'd I leave my car?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Hang on... Look who’s running in the sixth race. Curtis hands a newspaper folded on the race schedule to G

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dynamic Rainbow! Are you kidding me? Is that not our dog? Look me in the eye and tell me that’s not our dog! Gerry looks over the schedule, tempted.  11 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 16.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It’s a good name.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It’s a great name! Standing up, Gerry instinctively pats his left pant pocke check for his wallet. Nothing there. Curtis notices, picks up a wallet sitting on the coffee t and tosses it to him.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Gerry holds his wallet awkwardly, fighting against the ur look inside.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Go on. Count it. Gerry shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Naw, I don’t--

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: C'mon. It’s okay. He opens the wallet, quickly checks his cash and cards, t slips it into his left pocket.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Trusting a stranger, Gerry. It’s just one of those things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry enters his home through the side kitchen door with of mail. He flips on the light switch, but nothing happen turns the switch off and on again. Still nothing. He mutt to himself, but doesn’t appear surprised that the electri has been shut off.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Honey, I’m home. A cat approaches him, meowing like crazy.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know, I’m sorry, sweetheart. He puts some food in her bowl.  12 13 14 15 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 17. INT. GERRY’S BATHROOM 12 Gerry sits on the toilet, when he notices the empty roll him. Still seated, he leans over, opens the cabinet benea sink. No extra rolls. GERRY. Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry changes his clothes in a hurry, when his cell phone He checks the number, sees an incoming call from SAM, and declines it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing dark shades to conceal his hangover, Gerry fumble a huge key ring outside the front door. He can’t find the key for this home’s lock.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Okay, I think this is it... He jams the key in and furiously wiggles it, but it won’t

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nope. We’ll get there. He tries another one.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m finally starting to understand what you're after. And I think this one’s a real winner. A WIDER ANGLE reveals a YOUNG COUPLE waiting on the porch Gerry as he tries yet another key.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry about this, folks. They nod, politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the newlyweds examine the kitchen, Gerry fixates on interaction from the hall, trying to get a read on them. couple speak in hushed tones.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I really wanted gas, honey.  16 17 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 18.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Well, could we switch it out?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Where'd he go?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: He’s over there.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: A gas range would be nice. ON GERRY as phone vibrates. He turns away from the couple and checks an incoming text a photo of Curtis at the dog track with the text reading to dynamic rainbow!” Gerry smiles, thinks for a beat, then--

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. GERRY'S CAR
dialogues.text: Gerry drives on the highway talking to Curtis on his phon

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’m on my way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We intercut with Curtis at the track.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Our race is up in twenty minutes. What’s your ETA?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: About fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Okay, good. Do you want me to place a bet for you? They’re saying Dynamic Rainbow has 48 to one odds.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: 48 to one?! That’s terrible.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: That’s what makes it fun, Gerry. I’m laying fifty to win. What do you want to do?  18 19 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 19.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: 48 to one? Geez, I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You can bet to place if you want.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: How many dogs are racing?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Eight. First or second to place.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Uh, let me think...

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Don’t stress, baby; it’s just dogs.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Put me down for two hundred to place.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Okay, see you soon. Gerry sets down his phone and turns up his “200 Poker Tel audio book on the stereo. JOE NAVARRO’S VOICE Number nine. Nodding approval when strong. Inadvertently, people will nod affirmatively when they realize they have the best hand. Sometimes it looks like the person is just rocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry runs through the lot toward the main entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters the grandstand area, where a fantastic assortme oddball characters are assembled on a weekday afternoon-- of them over 60 and smoking. Gerry spots Curtis at the bar holding court with the regu He has them laughing and wheezing.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Gerry, you made it! (handing Gerry his half full cup) Have a beer.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 20.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Thanks. How’s it going?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: We're up next. Our dog is so beautiful, Gerry. They walked it through, you should have seen it.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Good legs?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Great legs. Strong, but agile. He’s a real winner.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I can’t remember the last time I’ve been to a dog track.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: But you love cats. Am I right? Gerry stares at Curtis. How could he possibly know this? Curtis pinches a clump of cat hair off Gerry’s coat. Gerr smiles, tries to brush off the remaining cat hair.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’m more of a poker man. Poker and sports.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It’s a sport for dogs. C’mon, let’s get closer. (to the regulars) Good luck you beautiful losers!

dialogues.speaker: LOSER
dialogues.text: Give’m hell, weirdo! Curtis and Gerry stroll to the seating area.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Did you know Herbert Hoover was the first U.S. President born west of the Mississippi?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I did not.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Right here in Iowa.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You win anything yet?  Alg OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 21.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m only here for one race. ON THE TRACK. The dogs step into the starting gate. A19 GRANDSTAND. A commotion erupts behind Curtis and Gerry as betters cheer on a horse from the off-track-betting monit Drawn in by the excitement, Gerry turns around to watch. notices, pulls his attention back towards the dogs.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Be here now, Gerry. This is the only race.

dialogues.speaker: HERE COMES RUSTY
dialogues.text: A HORN sounds and the dogs sprint out of the gate, chasin furry lure (Rusty) attached to a mechanical arm.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Here we go! The announcer provides a moment by moment description of race as the dogs tear into the first turn.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I can’t see. Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: C'mon rainbow!

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Coming out of the first turn it’s Goldilocks followed by Mystery Train. As the other spectators cheer on their picks, a cacophony voices shouting out different numbers nearly drowns out t announcer’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Where is he? Which number’s ours?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Number four! *

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Coming up on the outside is Dynamic Rainbow.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Dynamic Rainbow!  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 22.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: C'mon rainbow!

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Cc’mon four! As the dogs come into the home stretch, we see dog #4 (Dy Rainbow) move up into second place. Gerry and Curtis go n urging on their dog.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: C'mon rainbow!

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hot damn! C’mon rainbow! Dynamic Rainbow is now even with the leader as they appro finish line. Gerry lets out a howl.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: And it’s Dynamic Rainbow by a nose. Curtis screams, hugs Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What? What did he say? Curtis doesn’t respond, but continues to dance in celebra breaking into song...

dialogues.speaker: CURITS
dialogues.text: “Somewhere over the rainbow...” The realization finally sets in and Gerry joins in the celebration dance as if he just scored the winning touchd the Superbowl. He screams and points at the other spectat which may go against proper track etiquette, but who care The triumph is short-lived, however, as Gerry is suddenly overcome with despair.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I fucking bet to place!

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You still won big.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’m an idiot! Why didn’t I listen to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 23.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Gerry, we won. Let’s go celebrate! We'll get some drinks, meet some ladies, go to a show...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Go where? I love this place. We can have drinks here, meet ladies here.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Gerry, Gerry, Gerry... It don’t get any better than this. Let’s go have some fun!

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I just got here! Okay, listen to this... next person through that door--

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Gerry--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: If the next person through that door is wearing glasses, we stay for one more.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You’re on. They look over to the men’s room door, where a gray-haire with a cane and glasses, steps out. Gerry smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry and Curtis drink bourbon at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’1l tell you what, Gerry... never bet on a dog named after a disabled president.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I thought it was Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Rollin’ Roosevelt?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It was a good name.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It was not a good name. Next time listen when I say it’s time.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 24. Gerry’s phone registers a new message. He checks it, then it away, ignoring the text.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There was this guy back in Kansas City, Archie Hannahan. Never knew when to quit.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I know where this is going and you don’t need to tell me--

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Listen, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Archie owed every poker player in town at least a few hundred bucks. Got to the point where he was asking his little nephews for the change in their piggy banks. One day he’s in the poker room at Harrah’s. I walk over to say hello, notice he’s got a handsome pile of chips, over five grand. Archie starts bragging that he started the night with just sixty bucks-- sixty bucks he borrowed from some new chump, by the way. So I pull him aside, tell him he should cash out now. He’s got enough there to pay back everyone he owes and still get a slab at Oklahoma Joe's. “You're right, you're right,” he tells me. “I’1ll stop as soon as the blind comes around.” I smile, walk over to my table thinking I'd done a good deed... Next thing I hear is Archie's high-pitched voice saying... “I'm all in!”

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: And then he lost it all.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Of course he lost it all. But you know what he says to me? “Don’t worry. It was only sixty bucks.”

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Some guys are just born to lose.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 25. A burst of jubilation from the pool tables nearby draw Cu and Gerry’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You play?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: A little, but not in a long-- Before Gerry can finish, Curtis is calling out across the

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Hey! Twenty bucks on my friend here.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What’re you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m gonna watch you play this big winner here. You said you played.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It’s been a long time.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: So you'll lose.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No, you'll lose.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m spending twenty bucks to watch you make a fool of yourself. That’s not losing; that’s entertainment. Gerry smiles. Who does this guy think he is?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Okay. You want entertainment? Gerry strolls over to the Big Winner’s table.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s make it a hundred. Curtis’ demeanor suddenly shifts.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Whoa, hey, Gerry! Play nice now. Big Winner smiles, racks up the balls, as Gerry chalks hi and leans over the table. Curtis sips his drink, then--  21 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 26.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Five hundred! Gerry pauses, looks to Big Winner who is now looking a li less confident. He nods in agreement anyway. Not to be outdone, Gerry stares down Curtis, then...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Let’s play for a thousand. Curtis smiles, loving it, but Big Winner (and his friends not amused. OTHER FOLKS at the bar also begin to take not and step over. Gerry leans over the table, prepared to break, but Big Wi puts his hat over the cue ball--

dialogues.speaker: BIG WINNER
dialogues.text: That’s enough. You fellas don’t belong here, do you?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’m really not very good at this. Curtis steps over to the table, pulls Gerry away, while B Winner and his tough guy friends give hard looks.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Let’s go, Gerry. These guys don’t want our money. Curtis and Gerry head for the exit and we HOLD ON A SKINN watching them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis and Gerry stroll through the parking lot, laughing

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I can't believe you almost blew a thousand bucks of my money.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I just saved you from losing twenty... So what are you up to tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I think it’s Macchu Picchu time for me.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Say again?  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 27.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Time for me to hit the road. Gerry tries to conceal his disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, it was great to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You too, Gerry. Good luck. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You need a ride someplace?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Nah, I’m just gonna steal a bike. Gerry smiles, watches Curtis drift away, then wanders ove his car. He reaches into his pocket, fumbling with his ke when the skinny thug from the bar approaches him with a cigarette in hand.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Hey man, you got a light? Beat. Gerry looks the guy over.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Uh, no, sorry... Suddenly, the thug pulls out a switchblade.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aw man, what’s that for?

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Gimme the money.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I don’t have any money.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Thousand dollar bets? I heard you back there.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I can’t believe this.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Just give it to me!  22 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 28.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I told you, I don’t have any money! I lost it on Rollin’ Roosevelt.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Don’t make me cut you. The thug threatens him with the knife. Gerry is getting nervous.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Okay, just relax.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Hurry up! Gerry takes out his wallet. Flashes it. Empty.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: See?

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Do I look stupid? A burst of LAUGHTER breaks out from the pool hall exit. Startled, the thug reacts by stabbing Gerry in the belly deep) and booking it out of there. Gerry cups his stomach checks his hand, now bloodied by the wound.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Damnit! Gerry realizes the thug dropped his knife before running. picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You forgot this, asshole! He throws the knife. Winces in pain. Gerry gathers himsel then climbs in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry steps into the diner, looks around, and spots SAM (Samantha, a gentle-looking woman in her 50s). She hugs G like they’re old friends having a reunion. Gerry hugs her but we sense his discomfort.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 29.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It’s so great to see you, Gerry. How long’s it been?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t know. A few months now.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Too long. It’s been too long. You've been avoiding me, haven’t you?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No, I-- The WAITER steps up.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: (to Gerry) Can I bring you anything to drink?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Um, coffee, please.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Forgive me, I got here a few minutes early, and ordered a salad. But order anything you like. It’s on me.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Oh, no, that’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Of course, it’s okay. I insist.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Thank you. I’11 have a burger, medium- rare. And fries. The waiter walks away.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And how are you?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh, you know, same old grind. I’d love to retire soon, but it feels like a long way off. How’s the real-estate?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Slow and low.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: That’s too bad. I’m sure it’1l pick up.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 30.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Eventually. A long, awkward pause. Gerry tunes in to the details of S behavior: her nail CLICKING against her coffee mug, her F SMILE, the narrowing of her eyes as she stares at Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Don’t make me ask, Gerry... Gerry straightens up, as the waiter returns with a salad.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unbelievable. Excuse me, I asked for the dressing on the side.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry. Do you want me to take it back?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I want you to hold it between your knees. The waiter stares at her, confused.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Gerry) He doesn’t get it... Yes, take it back, please. The waiter takes off with the salad, and Sam calls after

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m here three days a week and every time with the dressing. Oh, boy. What’re you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What’re you gonna do? Another odd beat. An uncomfortable tension is mounting.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, look-- I had eight hundred last night and some meth head robbed me by knife point and stabbed me in the gut. He lifts up his shirt, revealing the blood-stained bandag GERRY (CONT’D) See?  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 31.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh, god, you should have that checked out. Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thankfully.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I can’t imagine.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It was pretty scary.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Well, at least you’re okay.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Just a scratch.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Could have been a lot worse ya know? Beat. Gerry sips his coffee, recognizing Sam’s veiled thr

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what did you bring me today? Gerry nervously opens his wallet, hands over everything i

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: That’s about eighty. I’11 have more for you next week. I mean I had eight hundred, but--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: --the meth head.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: The fucking meth head.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It was a bad beat.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: The worst.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Things’1l look up.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: They always do.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Well... not always.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 32. Another threat. Another tense beat. The waiter returns wi Sam’s salad.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: That’s okay. I’m sorry about that knees comment. It’s from a movie. I couldn’t resist. Sam’s phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you mind? Gerry shakes his head. Sam answers.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yeah... Oh geez, c’mon Laura... I can’t bring it to you at school, I’m ina meeting right now... Call your dad... How should I know?... It’s not my fault you forgot it... Maybe you shoulda thought about that before you went out last night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She covers the phone and whispers to Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Teenagers. Gerry puts on a false smile.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Okay, you know what, I’m gonna do this for you, but this is the last time... Do you hear me?... Okay, sweetie, I’11 be by in half an hour... Don’t keep me waiting out front either... Sam hangs up, returns her gaze to Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re lucky you don’t have to deal with this shit, Gerry, I tell ya.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I hear ya.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What am I gong to do with you?  23 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 33.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Next week, Sam. Don’t worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, Gerry. I’11 have Tim drop you a visit.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Oh, hey, that won’t be necessary... No need to bring him into this. If you could just give me a few more days, I have a commission coming in--

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: --Get it together, Gerry. Sam stands up and lays $40 of Gerry’s money on the table. puts his hand over hers.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I had the money.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I’m sure you did.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: This time it wasn’t my fault.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I understand. Sam yanks her hand back and starts walking away.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Just a few more days! Things are turning around for me. You'll see... But she’s out the door. Gerry slumps back in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open area office with about a dozen desks stationed ar the room. Most people are gone for the day, but Gerry and secretary are still there. The secretary packs up her bag

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna head out now, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Okay, see you tomorrow. The secretary leaves Gerry alone in the office. He finish scribbling some notes, then files them away in his drawer sits alone. (This is no kind of life.) Hold.  24 25 26 27 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 34.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY'S DESK
dialogues.text: Gerry opens the top drawer and removes a petty cash box. pockets the cash, then heads to the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry grabs several rolls of toilet paper, stuffing them his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounded by hanging tarp and construction materials, SI sit around a card table, playing poker, Gerry among them. The other players banter back and forth, relaxed and frie but Gerry sits low in his chair, playing quiet and tense. He watches as another player collects a pile of chips. New cards are dealt, and Gerry takes a peek. He folds his immediately, slouches deeper into his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry drinks, slumped over the bar-- the same bar he met in. He’s been there awhile, but orders another bourbon. H mumbles to himself as he pulls a crumpled single and a ha of change from his pocket, counting out the last of his c He stares at the pile of change on the bar counter, think then takes out his phone, dials...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (trying to sound upbeat) Hey, Curtis!

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (muffled through phone) Gerry!

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I know you're probably halfway to New Orleans by now, but--

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Crazy day, Gerry! I went to Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, I won a ticket to a Bulls game shooting dice this morning. So I went. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I’m back in your neck of the woods now.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (perking up) You are? Where? In the bg, we see Curtis enter the bar in a Chicago hat.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Same place we met the other night. Gerry and Curtis are now staring at each other across the

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What place? Curtis smiles and Gerry shouts with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Two Woodfords!

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yes! This is good. This means something.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You walking in the door just as I was calling you... It’s a sign.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Okay...  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 36.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Last night, after you left, some guy cut me in the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Cut you? Gerry raises his shirt, revealing gauze bandaged over the ON CURTIS.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You should get that looked at.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It’s not serious.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Did you know the guy?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, we play softball on weekends. No, I didn’t know him. He was mugging me.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Okay, take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Listen, what I’m getting at here--

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Does it hurt?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No-- it stings a little. What I’m getting at, Curtis... Good things happen to me when you’re around. Bad things when you leave. Where is this going?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was just sitting here thinking before I picked up the phone. I was thinking about that big home game in New Orleans. The disassociated guy.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Tony Roundtree?  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 37.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I want in.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: That game has a twenty five thousand dollar buy-in.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Okay. That’s a lot... That’s a lot. But I have a plan.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: We head down the Mississippi.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: We head down the Mississippi like Huck fucking Finn and Jim.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: On a raft.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: In a car. My car. We hit up all the action along the way. I know some weekly home games. Riverboats. Memphis. Vicksburg.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Tunica.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Absolutely, Tunica!

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m still listening.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’m in a hole now, but I’m climbing out. All I need is for you to stake me five hundred out the gate.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Oh boy, here we go...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No, it’s not-- look, it’s an investment. I/’11 play. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll be my lucky charm. We split the winnings even-steven. Curtis takes a beat to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What about your job?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: They won’t miss me.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a personal question?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You may.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: How much money do you owe?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: A lot.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: To who? Gerry thinks of the best way to answer this, then--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Everyone.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I gotta be honest with you, Gerry... I don’t think this is realistic.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’m a damn good poker player.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: That may be true--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: --this is very realistic.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It is. It’s extremely realistic.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Not with five hundred...  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 39.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You'd be amazed what I can do with--

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’1l stake you two thousand. Your car, my cash. Hold on Gerry-- a little stunned, as if he’d never expect Curtis to go along with his plan. Then...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hot damn. That’s what I’m talkin’ about. 28 INT. GERRY’S HOUSE - MORNING 28 Gerry fills a second cat bowl with food. The cat meows he disapproval, so Gerry takes down two more bowls and fills next to the others. He opens his dark refrigerator and dumps the rotting food garbage bag. Gerry picks up his cat, gives her a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Wish me luck. 29 EXT. GERRY’S CAR - OUTSIDE DENISE’S HOUSE - DAY 29 “200 Poker Tells” plays on the stereo, as Gerry taps the Curtis comes out with his leather duffel bag, climbs in t

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Where’s your cat?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: My house.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You just left her all alone?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: She’1ll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Uh-huh... Curtis slams the door, and they pull away. 30 INT. GERRY’S CAR - MINUTES LATER 30 Heading southbound on the highway.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 40.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Tony Roundtree once had a pet tiger.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: A pet tiger?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: He won it playing baccarat with an Arab prince. Cleans the guy out, the prince doesn’t want to stop playing so he puts his tiger on the table-- not literally, but you know.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Joke was on Tony, though. Didn’t know he’d be hemorrhaging money on the thing. He’s got to register it with the federal government, get a special permit. Costs a fortune. And he can’t leave it alone for more than a few hours or it rips up his furniture. Not easy to find a pet sitter for a carnivorous tiger, so what’s the guy do when he travels? Curtis pauses for effect. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First time I met him was on the bar car of an Amtrak train from Denver to Albuquerque. I remember he wore a blue velvet smoking jacket and drank from a copper flask. Gerry nods, developing a picture of Tony Roundtree in his

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: And the tiger...?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Tranquilized and checked with the other cargo.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: He checked a tiger? On an Amtrak train?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Apparently they have a policy. But wanna know what it costs to check a 600 pound animal?  31 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 41. Beat. Gerry shrugs, waiting for it. But Curtis’s attentio suddenly drawn to the car radio. JOE NAVARRO’S VOICE Number twenty-three: Dilated Pupils...

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Hold on-- what’re we listening to?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: This is “200 Poker Tells” by Joe Navarro. It relaxes me. JOE NAVARRO’S VOICE When we are comfortable or like something, our pupils dilate. We have no control over this and with players that have blue or green eyes, it can be quite visible. Remember, sudden pupil dilation says, “I like what I see.”

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: How often do you listen to this?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Whenever I’m driving.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Are you gonna make me listen to this all the way to New Orleans?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: We don’t have to listen to it.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Thank you. Curtis ejects the CD, hooks up an AUX cable to his iPhone funky blues song begins to play. At first hesitant, Gerry begins to bob his head, enjoying the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry’s car cruises past a highway sign: “St. Louis 211 m  32 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 42. EXT/INT. GERRY’S CAR - LATER THAT DAY 32 The music in play. he checks didn’t last long, as Gerry has “200 Poker Tells” back Curtis is asleep next to him. Gerry’s phone rings and the call. Declines it. Curtis stirs awake.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You bring any snacks?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I have some jerky in the backseat. Grab me some too. Curtis leans into the back seat, comes back with a plasti grocery bag and a cigar box.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Nice! You brought cigars?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Oh no that’s not-- Curtis opens the box to find a random assortment of items

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What’s all this?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Nothing. It’s an emergency fund. Just in case.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: In case of what?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Emergency. Curtis looks through the box, finds a couple watches, sev rare coins, vintage baseball cards, and--

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: This a wedding ring?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Get outta here; you were married?  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 43.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hard to believe, huh?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean it like that... What happened?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: She left. Before Curtis can respond, Gerry turns up the car radio v Curtis watches Gerry, who stares straight ahead, trying t on Joe Navarro’s voice. Clearly, this is still a sore sub JOE NAVARRO’S VOICE False smiles are used by bluffers. They look odd because sometimes only one side of the face is involved or the smile goes towards the ear rather than the eyes. It is an obvious sign of weakness and lack of confidence...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry waits behind Curtis as he KNOCKS on a cabin door. A redhead, (SIMONE, 30s) answers.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Hi. She stares at him, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Simone.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m wondering if you might be able to help me find a woman?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: What sort of woman you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Oh, about this tall...  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 44. He extends his hand to her height, then describes her fea

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cinnamon hair... soft pale skin... devastating blue eyes... They exchange long, familiar grins. Gerry looks on, waiti the payoff.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Hmm, I think I’ve seen this woman you're looking for.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (leaning in to her) I know she’s close. I’ve been tracking her sweet scent for miles.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: (pulling away) They say working class hound dogs have the best sense of smell.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Woof woof.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Well don’t just stand there barking, little doggy. Come inside and get yourself a treat. We hold on Gerry wondering what the hell is going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry and Curtis enter the tight cabin, which is being us dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Gerry, meet Simone. Simone hands them each a coat on a hanger.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: These were the best I could do.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Did I ever tell you you’re amazing?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Too often to feel sincere. As Curtis begins to disrobe, Gerry looks for a private pl put on his suit.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 45. His eyes stop on a cracked curtain, where a topless woman is applying makeup in front of a vanity mirror. He stares beat too long, until she notices and he looks away. She s and slides the curtain shut.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t be shy, Gerry, we’re all friends. Gerry smiles awkwardly, starts unbuttoning his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You guys play poker?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: No, we just work here, honey.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What is it you do?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Vanessa and I get paid for our companionship.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Oh... Got it. VANESSA-- the woman from the bathroom-- emerges in a gown Gerry is now topless.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: (re: his gut bandage) What happened there?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It’s nothing.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Doesn’t look like nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’m Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Vanessa. Vanessa and Gerry shake hands.  35 36 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 46.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Gerry saved my life in a knife fight.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: That’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Hi Curtis... How was Peru?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Not yet, sweetie. But it’s on the horizon, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: (to Gerry) You can change in there if you want it.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE CURTAIN 35
dialogues.text: Gerry shuts himself in the dressing area, looks in the mi He pulls back the bandage to reveal a red and swollen wou grimaces, then replaces the bandage. Gerry scrunches his face to release tension like we saw h in the opening scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the front deck, we see clearly for the first time th are floating down the Mississippi River on a private stea Suited up in cheap ill-fitting coats and sipping champagn Curtis and Gerry stare at the St. Louis skyline drifting

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: First thing when we get to New Orleans we buy new suits.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I don’t really wear suits.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Well we can’t go to Tony’s dressed like this.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: In that case, I’ve always wanted a white suit. Beat. Curtis and Gerry look out at the sunset, fantasizin about what their futures hold.  37

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Mental note: next trip, open sea.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What's this about Peru? (off Curtis’s look) You told Vanessa...

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It’s kind of a joke. Like when I 47. m done with a place or a person. When it’s time to move on, I’1l say, “It’s Machu Picchu time.”

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Machu Picchu time?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You might say it’s the end of my rainbow... A place so exotic and mysterious, I could get lost and never come back... And it’s fun to say. Machu Picchu. Try it.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Machu Picchu.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Machu Picchu.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Machu Picchu. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 Curtis and Gerry enter the ballroom, where a PIANO MAN is playing on a small stage. Six poker tables the cabin. The well-dressed guests (all of at various tables, while about a dozen sexy mingle on the perimeter of the cabin-- some provide table massages to players who don’t games. are spread around them men) play poker servers and escorts of these servers want to leave their Curtis stops to admire the music for a moment. Drops a $2 into the pianist’s tip jar.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’1l be at the bar if you need me. As Gerry takes his assigned seat, Curtis wanders to the e bar. While he waits for the bartender, he watches Gerry..  38 39 40 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 48.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TABLE 38
dialogues.text: Gerry checks the pair of cards he’s dealt and puts in a c chips to meet the blind. As the flop is dealt, Gerry slou in his chair ever so slightly. When the betting comes aro him, he thinks for a beat, then folds his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE BAR 39
dialogues.text: Curtis looks around, but still can’t find anyone to get h drink. IT’S THE FIRST TIME THAT WE’VE SEEN HIM ALONE, WIT

dialogues.speaker: AN AUDIENCE, AND HE DOESN'T QUITE KNOW WHAT TO DO WITH HI
dialogues.text: He scans the room, notices Simone giving a massage to one players. He watches for an extended beat, until she looks making brief eye contact. Curtis motions for her to come but she turns away. Desperate, Curtis stands up, starts slow dancing with an invisible partner until Simone can't ignore him anymore. laughs. Curtis smiles, takes a bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The steamboat cruises up a desolate section of the river. Curtis leans against the railing, while Simone sits on a smoking.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Tell me something I don’t know about St. Louis.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: I’ve only been here a few months.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: That’s no excuse. I was in Iowa for a few days and I can tell you that Marion Robert Morrison was born in Winterset, Iowa, 1907.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Am I supposed to know who that is?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You probably know him by his stage name: John Wayne. I can also tell you that Iowa is the only state in the country that begins with two vowels. And that the National Balloon Museum in Indianola chronicles more than 200 years of ballooning history--  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 49.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Okay, fine. I don’t know if this is true...

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (sitting next to her) Doesn’t matter. Lay it on me.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: You know how some hotels put little chocolates on pillows for their guests? That was started in St. Louis by... You’re supposed to guess who.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Ben Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Close. Cary Grant. Apparently, he was staying in the Mayfair and wooing a certain lady friend with chocolates on her pillows. Curtis smiles at first, but then...

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: A friend.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: I don’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: C'mon, think about it.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: What are you getting at?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Were you in a hotel room when this friend told you about Cary Grant’s chocolate seduction technique?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: I don’t remember, but so what if I was? Beat. Curtis lets it die.  4l OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 50.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Six months is a long time, Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Six months? It hasn’t been six months.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: September, October, November, December, January, February, March... Seven months. Beat. Curtis looks out over the water.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Tell me something else about St. Louis. INT. STEAMBOAT BALLROOM - LATER 4l Gerry, now with a large stack of chips, goes head to head guy in a bow-tie... Let’s call him THE PROFESSOR. Vanessa a neck massage to a different player at the table, watchi the tension mounts. On the table, the Ten and Nine of spades are displayed al the King of diamonds. A significant mound of chips is alr in play. Gerry, holding two spades (the King and Four) has a pair Kings with a good chance for a flush. There is also a str opportunity on the board, if his opponent can make a Quee Gerry places a bet for five hundred dollars, and the Prof raises the pot to a thousand. Gerry quietly meets the bet The TUXEDOED DEALER lays down the turn... the three of he which can’t help anyone. Gerry studies his opponent. Could he have the straight? G doesn’t bet this time around, checking to the Professor.. .+-who confidently tosses in a thousand dollars in chips. Gerry meets the thousand, and everyone at the table waits the last card... A seven of hearts. Gerry doesn’t make his spade flush. With only the pair of Kings, he checks.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 50A. The Professor calmly counts out his chips and...  42 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 51. ...pushes all of them towards the center of the table. Ho Gerry looking for the tell.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: How do you get a sweet, little old lady to shout, “Go fuck yourself!” Some players smile or chuckle, but Gerry focuses his atte on the Professor.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You get another sweet little old lady to shout, “Bingo!” Vanessa and the other players genuinely laugh. Gerry’s op attempts to give a carefree chuckle, however it comes off fake. He’s got him. Gerry meets the bet, calling the Professor's bluff. The Professor mucks his cards to the dealer, frustrated. rakes in the pot, giving Vanessa a wink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few locals play pool, while Simone/Vanessa select and d songs on the jukebox. Still in their elegant evening wear ladies stand out in this low-key dive. AT THE BAR. Gerry and Curtis, jackets off and ties loosen around their necks, sip bourbon side by side.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Did you hear the one about the gambler and the mugger? Gerry nods, yes.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Let me tell it. A gambler is walking down a dark alley, when a guy steps out with a gun, says “Your money or your life.” The gambler shrugs, “I’m sorry I’m a gambler, so--"”

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: “--I have no money and no life.”

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You've heard this before. Gerry laughs.  43 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 52.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was once mugged by an old lady ina wheelchair. Gerry laughs even harder now. Simone calls to them from t jukebox.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: You boys just gonna sit there all night?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Come dance with us. Gerry and Curtis exchange grins. Curtis hops off his ass joins the ladies in dance. We hold on Gerry watching them for a beat, until Vanessa him over. He downs his drink and joins them. INT. SIMONE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 43 Our gang of four play drunken Trivial Pursuit in the livi room: boys vs. girls. They each have a stack of dollar bi but the girls’ is significantly larger. Simone stops her on a blue square.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What city created a museum in the three- story home where Sigmund Freud lit up his last cigar?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: I know this, I think... London?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (checking the answer) Yes! How did you know that? Gerry hands the ladies another bill.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I would have guessed Vienna.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Simone's so smart. I never know anything.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You knew Joe Piscopo.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Everyone knew Joe Piscopo.  44 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 53.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: I didn’t know Joe Piscopo, baby. Curtis, will you come to the bedroom and rub my feet? Curtis and Gerry exchange smiles. Curtis follows Simone.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Duty calls.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Should we keep playing?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: That’s okay, I think I’ve had enough trivia for one night.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Do you know any magic tricks?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Not really. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: You wanta see?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Okay, I’m still learning so you can’t make fun of me.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I won’t make fun of you. Vanessa smiles and gets up to prepare her trick while Ger pours them two more drinks. INT. SIMONE’S ROOM 44 Simone and Curtis lie in bed as he massages her feet.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Where’d you find him?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Poker tournament with a sixty dollar buy-in. He was wearing a collared shirt with a missing button.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: And you ordered him a Woodford.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 54. Curtis smiles. She knows him too well. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s he need the money for?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: He believes it will set him free.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: I’m asking a serious question.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m giving an honest answer.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: I just want to make sure you know what you're getting into.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, he’s a good guy.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: That’s what you said about George.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You mean Jorge? What do you have against Jorge?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: His name was George. And he was a liar and a thief.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: He was not.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: What’s in this for you?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: The journey is the destination, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: That’s not an answer. It’s a bumper sticker.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: There’s nothing in it for me.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: So what then? After New Orleans. What’s next?  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 55. Curtis thinks for a beat, then--

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You should come with us.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’ve never been more serious.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: You know I have school.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: So play hooky.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Curtis...

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: We could have a great time.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: I have different priorities now. I can’t just hit the road on a whim.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Didn't your mama ever tell you you can do anything you want?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: No. She didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Well then I’m saying it for her. Beat. Simone decides to call his bluff.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: I‘’11 come with you.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Great. Simone yanks a suitcase out of the closet, tosses it on t  45 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 56.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: What should I pack for this little mystery tour?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Jackets? Will I be cold? How bout a bikini? I love the beach. Will you help me pick out some dresses? Is there a gym where we’re going? Suppose I‘1l need my running shoes. She starts throwing everything into the suitcase. Manic. Curtis just watches.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, can’t forget my heels. What about condoms? Will I have to work on this journey, or will you be providing a per diem?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: That’s enough. Simone tosses another stack of clothes onto Curtis. They facing opposite directions on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1l come back.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Don’t bother. I’11 be gone.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Not sure yet. Maybe Peru. It’s the one place I know you’1ll never be... INT. SIMONE’S LIVING ROOM 45 Now wearing a long coat, Vanessa struggles through her tr Gerry. The build up is not very impressive, however, she eventually reveals a small kitten up her sleeve. Gerry is genuinely stunned.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hot damn! What the fuck is that? She hands him the kitten.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 57.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was amazing!

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: You liked it?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I loved it. Where did this thing come from?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: It’s Simone’s. I was hiding him earlier so I could show you guys my trick tonight.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Don’t you know magicians never reveal their secrets? She blushes.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: I’m still learning, I guess. Don’t tell anyone, okay?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Your secret’s safe with me.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Your turn.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I told you I don’t know any tricks.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Well, I showed you mine, you have to show me yours. It can be anything. Gerry looks around the room, sees an old upright piano.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Okay, but you can’t make fun of me.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: I promise. Gerry sets the cat down, moves over to the piano bench. H begins to play a beautiful and haunting classical piece. Vanessa watches him for a beat, then sits next to him on bench. She stares at his fingers in wonder, while Gerry p with his eyes closed.  46 47 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 58. INT. SIMONE’S ROOM 46 Curtis is putting Simone’s strewn clothes back into the c when he pauses upon hearing the piano from the other room gets lost in the music for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Is that Vanessa?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Must be your friend. Curtis looks off, the piano triggering something in him.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I didn't know Gerry played.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Why would you? You met him two days ago.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: He’s not bad. Curtis listens by the door.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Curtis Vonn, you're a little boy living in a grown man’s body. One day you’re gonna wake up old and realize you blew your last nickel on a deadbeat loser don’t even know your last name. Curtis hears this, but pretends not to. INT. SIMONE’S LIVING ROOM 47 After finishing the short piece, Gerry looks to Vanessa.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: I liked that.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah? She nods. They stare at each other for an extended beat. is the moment he should lean in for a kiss, but... ..-he turns away.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Are you married? Gerry shakes his head.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 59.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Girlfriend? Gerry just stares at the piano keys.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I have a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: Yeah? That’s cute. Do you have a picture? Gerry shakes his head, ashamed that he doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: She lives with her mom in Little Rock.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: That’s not so far away. Beat. Gerry runs his fingers across the piano keys as if change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you wanta kiss me? Gerry nods, then--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I have problems with money.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
