dialogues.text: (offended? ) Did I say anything about money?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No. I’m sorry, I didn’t mean it like that. It’s just the first thing that came to mind, so... I said it. Vanessa nods.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA
dialogues.text: I’m gonna do something with my life. I may not have it all figured out yet, but... I’m gonna do something. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's the first thing that came to my mind. Gerry smiles.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 60.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you play another song? Gerry begins to play another song. Vanessa rests her head his shoulder, while he plays. Hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry's car speeds by a sign reading, “Memphis 190 miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis pumps gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry listens to his voicemail message as he tends to his stomach wound in front of the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY'S BOSS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gerry, we hope you're okay. A little concerned that we haven’t heard from you. It’s all a bit awkward, but I feel I need to mention that some of the petty cash seems to have gone missing-- Not that I’m accusing you of taking it... but Janice says there was a hundred fifty there when she left on Tuesday... Also a friend of yours named Tim stopped by? Said he’s been looking for you too... 51 EXT/INT. GERRY’S CAR 51 Gerry looks a little stressed as “200 Poker Tells” plays. JOE NAVARRO’S VOICE Number 118. Sitting Lower and Lower. Players who slip lower and lower in their chairs during a hand, are progressively revealing their weakness. Most players are not aware of how low or high they sit. It is a very accurate tell on some players whose posture is governed by their emotional state.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: That’s yours, ya know?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What?  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 61.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You're a sloucher. It’s your tell. You slouch when you’re worried.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You're doing it right now. Gerry sits up, correcting his posture.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ever considered Yoga?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m just saying, helps with the posture. Gerry shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seemed like Vanessa really liked you.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, we had a nice time.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Did you sleep with her?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No. Curtis just stares at him. GERRY (CONT’D) What?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It wasn’t that kind of thing between us.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I thought you knew how to read people. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She was sending signals all night.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Maybe I didn't feel like it.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Do you like women?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It's okay if you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What’s going on with you and Simone?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: We had sex last night.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: That’s not what I asked.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Why are you changing the--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: --Your voice goes up an octave when you talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Okay okay...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: All soft and dreamy. You must really love this girl.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You're avoiding the subject, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: And what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What are you afraid of?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Afraid? I’m not afraid... What are you talking about? 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis thinks this over for a second. Something clicks.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Your ex-wife.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: That’s what this is all about. She left you and you want her back. I should’ve known it was about a woman.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It’s not about-- a woman. Curtis stares at Gerry for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Yes, it is. You know how I know? You're slouching.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You don’t know anything.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I know a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You know how to bullshit, I’1l give you that.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’ve met a lot of people on the road, Gerry. I know what makes them tick.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you’re just a regular Dr. Phil.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m just saying that my experience has given me certain insights into human behavior.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: How old are you? Beat. Curtis knows where he’s going.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Forget what?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I see what you’re doing and it doesn’t matter. Age is not the only indication of life experience.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’m forty-four. They drive in silence for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m thirty-nine.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No you’re not... Hundred bucks I can guess your age though.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You’re on. Beat. Gerry milks the moment.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Let’s see... I’d have to say you’re thirty... five.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m thirty-five. How’d you know that?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’m good with ages.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Good with ages, my ass.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I looked at your driver’s license.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: This morning. You were in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Why did you do that?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Just making sure you're who you said.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: And what did you learn? 64.  52 53 54 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 65.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You're Curtis Vonn. Thirty-five with * an expired North Dakota driver's license.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Something else you want to share? Curtis smiles, looks out the window. This guy may be tric than he thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON an OLDER GENTLEMAN speaking to Curtis who is jus screen.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: Muddy Waters, Howlin’ Wolf, B.B. King, Aretha Franklin, Al Green, Otis Redding, Isaac Hayes, John Lee Hooker, Booker T and the MGs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry on his phone pleading with another bookie.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hey J.P. Yeah, yeah, yeah. Just listen, listen-- put me down for five on Hawaii over Gonzaga tonight... Bullshit! I literally have the money right now, as we speak. In my hands... Hello? Hello? Gerry swears under his breath and pockets his phone.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE OTB AREA 54
dialogues.text: The Older Gentleman continues rattling off names to Curti Gerry approaches.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: There’s even some famous white folk from Memphis you mighta heard of... Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins, Johnny Cash, Sam Phillips-- he founded Sun Records...

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: All those people are from Memphis?  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 66.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: And don’t forget Justin Timberlake.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Very impressive, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (re: previous races) How we doing?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Won forty on Heart and Soul.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Lost fifty on Domino Effect. An OLD COUPLE bickers at a nearby table. Gerry and Curtis exchange smiles with the Older Gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How long were you married?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Eight years.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: That’s a long time.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Was supposed to be longer.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I like women too much to marry one... I’m going to get a burger. Want anything?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (checking watch) No. I should head over to this game soon.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (to Older Gentleman) You married, pops?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: I was married six times. But not at present.  55 56 57 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 67.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Wow. Well, here’s looking to lucky number seven. They toast and drink.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you miss the married life?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: Do I miss it? Well, let me put it like this... I just know it’s better to not be alone... Another eruption breaks out near the monitors as the dogs the finish line. Gerry and Curtis calmly turn their heads observe the winners’ and losers’ reactions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry plays poker with a group of six other players. Roun round they go... Gerry wins hand after hand.

dialogues.speaker: MEMPHIS BLUES BAR
dialogues.text: A sweaty, smoky, cramped juke joint. Perched on a bar sto Curtis watches a lean and mean Blues band play on stage. dance and sway in front of the musicians. A CURVY WOMAN in a tight dress saddles up next to Curtis, smiles. The music continues over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry continues to clean up at the poker table. His only competition is DONNA (a cigar-chomping southern diva, 50s is doing almost as well as Gerry in chip count. On the muted TV in the background, Gerry sees college bas scores on ESPN.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Shit! Dennis turns to see what Gerry’s responding to.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Wow. Hawaii beat Gonzaga? I didn’t even know they had a basketball team.  58 59 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 68.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: That’s a bigtime upset. You have money on the Zags, Gerry? ON GERRY. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hawaii. The name of their team is the Rainbow Warriors. The other players stare at Gerry waiting for an explanati

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis and his new friend are now dancing in front of the She appears to be teaching him a few new steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry peeks at his cards: an Ace and a Jack. He raises a amount. Two players fold, but Donna calls. The flop comes down with an Ace, a Jack and Three, giving two-pair on the flop. He studies Donna, who takes another peek at her cards, wh Gerry interprets as insecurity. Gerry raises a full grand Donna looks at Gerry, trying to read him. Her eyes search face. Gerry remains impassive, however Donna calls his ra again. The dealer discards the top card, then lays down the turn Another Ace. Gerry notes a glimmer in Donna’s eye when th is laid. She must also have an Ace, giving her three of a But Gerry has a full house, all face cards. Certain he has the best hand, Gerry does not want to appe overconfident. He takes his time, plays with his stack of chips, then finally checks, not betting any money. Donna looks him over. Gerry’s face reveals nothing. After beat, Donna pushes all of her chips (about 10K) into the She’s all in. Gerry smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Call. She looks to Gerry, a little less confident now...  60 61 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 69.

dialogues.speaker: MEMPHIS BLUES BAR 60
dialogues.text: The song ends and folks applaud. The woman leans close to Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Wanta go back to my place?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Thank you. I would love to see your place. I really would. But I’m just here for the music tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up with Gerry and Donna in the same hand... As pe rule, Donna turns over her cards... Ace/Queen. Gerry smil He was right. Three of a kind. He flips his cards. The other players gasp. Donna winces. With “the river” card still out, Donna can only win if a is dealt. A tense silence comes over the room as the deal burns the top card and... ...lays the “river” card face up. A Queen of spades. The gasps again. Gerry can’t believe his eyes. Donna lets out a huge sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I did not deserve that. Sorry, Gerry. She collects her huge stack of chips.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Tough break, Gerry. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Let’s go again.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Call it a night, Gerry, you don’t have enough to meet the blind.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’m good for another grand. C’mon, Dennis, tell her I’m good.  62 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 70.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: It’s a bad beat, Gerry. Throw in the towel. Gerry leans close to Dennis, speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’ve been takin’ her all night, man, I can get it back. Just loan me a few hundred.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: I can’t do it. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Dennis. It’s me you're talking to. How long have I known you?

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: A few years.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: A few years? C’mon, I’ve known you at least six years. Six years how many times have I asked you for money?

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Once.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Once. Wait once? Are you counting now as the one time?

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No? Gerry racks his brain, trying to remember.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did I pay you back? Dennis shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. MEMPHIS RESIDENTIAL STREET
dialogues.text: Gerry climbs in the driver’s seat, shuts the door. He clo his eyes. A quiet rage simmers as he grips the wheel tigh  63 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 71. We watch him tumble through a range of emotions, from ang laughter to despair, and then his phone vibrates... Insert: a text message from SAM, featuring a photo of a T NECKED TOUGH GUY in Gerry’s home, posing with his cat. Be it, the text reads, “Get home soon. Kitty misses u.” Gerry starts the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: MEMPHIS BLUES BAR 63
dialogues.text: Curtis chats up a motley crew of locals at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Hundred thousand dollar bet. The deal was Slim had to get C-cup breast implants and leave them in for exactly one year. No less.

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL
dialogues.text: Woman titties for a whole year?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Not only did he win the bet-- and he was paid, I can vouch for that. He met a woman-- a straight woman-- that loved his fake tits so much, she married him. And to this day, six years later, he’s still got’m, perky as ever. Everyone cracks up and cries bullshit, just as Gerry ente the background.

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) There’s someone out there for everyone. That’s what they say. We HOLD ON Gerry watching Curtis from afar, struggling wi to tell him what happened. Gerry scrunches his face, loosening the tension, psyching himself up. He stands up straight as an arrow, slowly sta bobbing his head to the music, and... ..-breaks out into a big smile. Curtis sees him approachi

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Gerry! How’d it go? Gerry leans close to Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I won seven thousand.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 72.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Holy shit! You sonuvabitch! Seven? Curtis embraces Gerry in a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C'mon, have a drink! Meet some people.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hang on a second--

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: C'mon, let’s celebrate--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: There’s something I have to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Can we talk in private?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step into an adjoining alley behind the bar.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what it means.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What what means?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Tonight. I was all-in on this monster pot. Dead in the water. Over my head. Down to the river I needed a queen. Only a queen could save me and I made a promise. I promised myself if I got a queen, I'd go to Little Rock and make things right. ON CURTIS, wheels turning.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Make things right with my queen. You know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Your ex-wife...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You were right.  65 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 73.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: A woman. Didn’t I tell you it was a woman? It’s always a woman.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: We go to Little Rock, that’s what we do.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: But it’s like two hours out of the way. Maybe it’s crazy. Am I crazy?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You're a lunatic. But I love it.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You don’t mind?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: A beautiful woman asked me to come home with her tonight, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I turned her down.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: When you come to a fork in the road, take it... Gerry isn’t sure what that means.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s go to Little Rock. EXT/INT. GERRY’S CAR - NIGHT 65 Gerry stares straight ahead behind the wheel while Curtis against the passenger seat window.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun rises over downtown Little Rock landmarks and sub area homes. 67 EXT. SUBURBAN STREET - DOROTHY’S HOUSE- EARLY MORNING A modest one-story ranch-style home with rain-stained alu siding and an American flag in the window. Gerry’s car is parked out front. Gerry steps up onto the porch. Knocks. Waits. After a few beats, DOROTHY (tired, 40s) opens the door an stunned recognition sweeps over her.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Gerry?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hi Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: What’re you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I was just passing through town. Thought I’d stop by to say hello.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: You were just stopping through Little Rock? An awkward beat as they stand in silence.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I don't have to stay. I just thought it would be nice to see you, even for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: (reluctant) Sure. Um... Come in, I guess. WITH CURTIS IN THE CAR. He watches from the driver's seat Gerry disappears inside the house. He smiles. 68 INT. DOROTHY’S HOUSE - DAY 68 Dorothy gestures for Gerry to sit at the table.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Have a seat. I was making some tea. Do you want some?  69 70 71 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 75.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Sure. Dorothy goes into the kitchen. Gerry pulls out a chair, which gets stuck on a stuffed an the floor. He picks up the stuffed animal and sits, nervo fidgeting with it as he glances around the room. He sees family photo of Dorothy and another man posing with a lit girl-- Gerry’s daughter, WENDY (6, adorable with curls). EXT. INSIDE GERRY’S CAR 69 Inspired by Gerry, Curtis picks up his phone, begins to d INT. DOROTHY’S LIVING ROOM 70 Dorothy returns with the tea.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Where's... where is Wendy?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: At school.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: That’s good... And how are things with Gary?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Things are good. Beat. They sip their tea. Gerry focuses in on little deta of Dorothy’s body, as if looking for “tells” in a poker opponent. Gerry’s POV: her tight pursed lips, tense jaw, blinking e her hand fidgeting with her wedding ring... She notices him looking at her hand.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We got married.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Congratulations. It’s even more awkward now. EXT. GERRY’S CAR 71 Curtis holds his cell phone to his ear. We hear muffled ringing, followed by Simone’s groggy voice--  72 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 76.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Curtis?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Hey darlin’.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Did I wake you? I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: We’re on a little detour in Little Rock.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: What happened to New Orleans?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m sitting in a car outside Gerry’s ex- wife’s house. He’s in there right now trying to win her back. And it got me thinking... about you, me, St. Louis, Kansas City... all kinds of places, really. INT. DOROTHY’S LIVING ROOM 72 With Gerry attempting to break the awkwardness.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Do you ever think it’s funny you traded me in for a Gary? She doesn’t. Gerry plots his next move, as Dorothy begins lose patience.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: He’s working.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Oh... what does he do?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: He’s an electrician. Gerry nods. Then he notices another photo on the wall.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 77. It features his daughter Wendy-- about 2 years old, sitti to a birthday cake, hugging a kitten (Gerry’s cat, a few younger). It’s a lovely photo, but something is amiss to

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Wait a second... He moves over to the photo, takes it off the wall.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was in this. You cut me out of this. That’s my hand. Right there. You can still see my hand.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I didn’t want you on my wall, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: So you just erase me from my daughter’s life?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Is that a joke? You erased yourself years ago.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No--

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: When’s the last time you visited or sent a present on her birthday?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You know I’ve been having a hard time with money, but--

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: It’s not about money. How about checking her homework or making dinner or, or just calling to say hi? A long pause. Gerry doesn’t have any answers, So...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Thanks for the tea. Can I use the bathroom before I go? Dorothy rolls her eyes, exasperated. Picks up his mug, br it to the kitchen. Gerry sets down the picture on a shelf (balanced precario as he makes his way down the hall. Before entering the bathroom, he turns back to make sure she isn’t watching, ducks through the bedroom door on the right.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 78. 73 EXT. GERRY’S CAR Curtis continues on phone...

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You sound sleepy, darlin’.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: I was up late studying.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Test today.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: That’s cute.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Teach me something.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: I’m tired, Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: C'mon... I just want to hear your voice. Sing me a song.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: I’m not going to sing you a song.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Please. Simone sings the alphabet song. Then silence.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What if I came back?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: After New Orleans. What if I came back and stayed with you for awhile? What would that look like?  74 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 78A.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: What would it look like? I don’t know. Normal. We'd look like normal people.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Normal people?

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Like everyone else. Eating and sleeping and fucking and fighting... Watching TV. What do you want me to say? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You said it.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Is that what you want? INT. DOROTHY’S BEDROOM 74 Gerry rummages through dresser drawers, looking for somet specific. After a few beats of searching, he finds it. A purple stocking. He smiles, amused that she keeps the sam hiding place after all these years. Gerry digs into the stocking, comes up with a wad of cash quickly counts out a stack of $100 bills. He puts the res in the stocking, returns it to its hidden position, and c the drawer. He pockets the cash and turns toward the door  75 76 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 79. --He’s busted. Dorothy is perched in the doorway watching A long awkward beat, but Dorothy doesn’t seem surprised. Ashamed, Gerry takes the cash out of his pocket and puts the dresser.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I was going to pay you back.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Get out. Gerry slowly squeezes past Dorothy, into...

dialogues.speaker: THE HALLWAY 75
dialogues.text: Gerry stops, turns to Dorothy. He wants to say so much, b he can manage is a pathetic shrug. Enough is enough. Dorothy shoves Gerry out of the hall an accidentally knocks over the photo of Wendy and his cat.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Shit! The glass SHATTERS on the floor, and Gerry kneels down to it up, but slices his hand in the process. He’s bleeding floor and broken picture frame.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Leave. Now. Still holding the photo, Gerry hurries towards the door. stuffs the bloodied photo in his pocket. EXT/INT. GERRY’S CAR 76 Still on the phone with Simone.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Simone...

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Yeah? A long beat. It feels like Curtis wants to say something, he notices Gerry come out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Good luck on your test, today.

dialogues.speaker: SIMONE
dialogues.text: Thanks.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 79R.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I have to go now... But I’1l call you soon-- from New Orleans. Okay? Curtis ends his call as Gerry gets in the car, slams the

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: As expected.  77 78 79 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 80.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: She was happy to see you?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Are you bleeding?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: C'mon, let’s go... Curtis starts the car, and they pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry sips coffee, stares out the window. Curtis takes a of his eggs, watching Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You wanta talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry shakes his head. They sit for a long moment, not ta And then... *

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I fucked up. *

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It’s okay. *

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t know what happened back * there. Maybe it didn’t work out this * time. Maybe it’s not my business. But * you took your shot and I’m proud of * you... You hear me? *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry stares at Curtis for a beat. Nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various shots of Tunica’s casino lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry and Curtis carry their bags toward the sparkling en Gerry has a bandage on his hand.  80 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 80A.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: This place loves me, Gerry. I’m like the Moe Greene of Tunica, Mississippi. We'll be comped for days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis and Gerry step up to the front desk. Curtis presen V.I.P. card. DORA (30s) speaks with a Mississippi accent.

dialogues.speaker: DORA
dialogues.text: Welcome back to Goldstrike.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (reading her name tag) Thank you... Dora. She swipes his card.

dialogues.speaker: DORA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, this expired in 2009.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 81.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DORA
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I don’t see how that’s possible. Try it again... Go easy now. She swipes the card again.

dialogues.speaker: DORA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (flirting) Well, Dora, I have to say I am very disappointed in you. Dora stays professional.

dialogues.speaker: DORA
dialogues.text: We do have some suites available for three ninety five a night. Curtis leans close, while Gerry looks on, uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (whispering) Don’t you think you could just push the right buttons and comp me one of those suites for old times sake?

dialogues.speaker: DORA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, sir. Curtis stares at her with a seductive grin, whispers.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What time do you get off work?

dialogues.speaker: DORA
dialogues.text: I'll be here til eleven.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Perfect. I’11 meet you in the player’s lounge at eleven fifteen?

dialogues.speaker: DORA
dialogues.text: I got a man.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What’s your man have to do with me?  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 82. She smiles, shows him her wedding ring.

dialogues.speaker: DORA
dialogues.text: (leaning in, quiet) I can give you the AARP discount. That’s ten percent off. Curtis smiles to Gerry as if he’s just managed to move mo with his charm.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What do ya say, Gerry?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Forget it, let’s go somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It's fine, we can afford one night.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (to Dora) How much is a regular room?

dialogues.speaker: DORA
dialogues.text: Ninety-nine dollars.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Little steep, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Give me the money, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (to Dora) Excuse me miss... This man is the Mel Greene of Tunica, Mississippi. Do you have any idea what that means? Dora stares at him. She doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He has a V.I.P. card. Can you please just comp us for the night? Please?

dialogues.speaker: DORA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, sir. I don’t have the authority--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Well, that’s just not acceptable. Can I speak to your manager?  81 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 83.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Hang on, Gerry. (to Dora) I’m sorry, will you excuse us a moment? Curtis escorts Gerry away from the desk and into the... INT. GOLDSTRIKE CASINO MEN’S ROOM 81 Gerry paces in front of the sinks, while Curtis interroga him.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Where’s the money?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What money? Curtis stares at Gerry, who stops pacing, slumps against sink counter.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're going to be all right.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What does that mean? Gerry doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gerry, your lips are saying we’re all right, but you’re slouching like a kid who just pissed his pants in the sandbox. Gerry straightens up. Still no response.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are we at, Gerry!?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (finally) Ground zero. I tried to tell you before.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You tried to tell me?  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 84.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Fucking cunt! I was nailing her all night and she lands a queen on fifth street.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Are you telling me you lost in Memphis?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I didn't know how to break it to you.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What were we doing in Little Rock? Gerry looks away, ashamed. Curtis is piecing it together.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No... Gerry shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Curtis turns away from Gerry toward the mirror, makes eye contact with himself. We hold on him for a long beat as h examines his reflection.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can win it back. I can get us to twenty-five.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It’s not about the money, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Of course it is! Do you think this is a vacation for me?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You're a piece of work, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I played it right. It wasn’t my fault. I can’t catch a break. I just - can’t - win! Curtis rubs his head, exasperated, then--

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: This story doesn’t have a happy ending. I think you should go back to Iowa.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 85.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No way. I can’t go back empty-handed. I need this. Don’t you see? I can’t go back! Gerry kicks a bathroom stall door and slips on his ass to floor. He’s a pathetic sight.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You're trying to lose.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah right, I’m trying to lose. Curtis stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not trying to lose!

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Gerry... You’re sitting in piss on the floor of a Mississippi casino bathroom stall. Now be honest with yourself... Gerry suddenly HOWLS from the depths of his soul, when... THREE FRATTY TYPES (20s) enter the bathroom and approach urinals.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT BOY
dialogues.text: What’s up faggots? His buddies laugh as they line up to PISS. CLOSE ON CURTIS. He looks over to Gerry on the floor. He shrugs as if apologizing in advance for what he’s about t Curtis takes his time walking over to the homophobic Frat stopping directly behind him. He lifts his leg and firmly nudges the Frat Boy in the ass until he is wedged up agai urinal, thus pissing on himself.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT BOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get off me! Curtis steps back and walks out of the bathroom, as Frat spins around, piss all over his pants. Before he even thinks to zip up, the Frat Boy starts towa exit door to chase after Curtis, when Gerry jumps to his distract him.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hey! Right here, tough guy. Let’s go!  82 83 84 85 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 86. Now confused, the Frat Boy turns his manly aggression tow Gerry. Charging forth and tackling him to the tile. His buddies zip up and join in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON CURTIS listening to the fight on the other side. PAN off of him to the door labeled “MEN”. HOLD for a beat before Curtis bursts back through the door, coming to Ger aide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry's car speeds by a sign, “New Orleans 310 miles”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cheap motor inn with a flickering vacancy sign. Gerry, face showing some wear and tear from the fight earlier, f ice bucket and hobbles back to the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirtless in his boxers, Curtis, who has somehow managed it out of the brawl unscathed, sits with his phone on the toilet. We hear muffled ringing, then Vanessa answers.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (muffled through phone) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Vanessa. It’s Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Is Simone there?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sorry, she’s not home.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Where is she? Her cell went straight to voicemail.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You don’t know? It’s almost midnight.  86 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 87.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: Gerry wraps ice in a hand towel, hears Curtis through the

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is she with someone? ON CURTIS IN THE BATHROOM.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t say you don’t know. I know you know. Is she with someone?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I promise I really don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Just tell me. I’11 stop asking if you tell me.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I don’t know. Maybe she’s studying.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: She’s not studying. Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I‘1l tell her you called.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: No, you know what, forget I called.

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m serious. Please. Don’t tell her I called. Can you do that for me? Vanessa? Don’t tell her. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Are you gonna tell her?

dialogues.speaker: VANESSA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Thanks. 86  87 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 88. Curtis hangs up, rubs his head in anguish. (He’s not accu to whatever he’s feeling now).

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL ROOM 87
dialogues.text: Curtis comes out of the bathroom, falls onto his bed.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Everything okay? No response. Gerry watches him for a beat, notices a miss pinky toe on Curtis’ left foot.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're missing a pinky.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Mm-hm.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Some crazy bastard bit it off ina bathroom brawl. Gerry disappears into the bathroom. After a few beats...

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I was eight, my sister and I went to live with our grandparents for a couple years. Gerry reappears, sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Old house on a hill. It was my job to mow the lawn. It was one of those old rusty rotating blade manual mowers. I can barely even push the thing but there I am, doing my best like Sisyphus up the hill... My little sister steps in front of me, starts screwing around, taunting me like kid sisters do... Whatever she’s doing, she’s not getting out of my way, so I tell her she has til the count of three...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Fair warning.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 89.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I thought so. But one, two, three come and go and she refuses to move, so I ran over her foot with the lawn mower. She lost three toes. Gerry winces. Curtis sips from the flask, when Gerry asks obvious...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: So how’d you lose a toe?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: My grandfather’s brilliant idea of justice... He drank a fifth of Jack, held me down and sliced it off with a weed clipper. Gerry let’s that sink in for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Where was this?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Minnesota.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Not North Dakota?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’ve lived all over.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Where’s your sister now? No response. They sit in silence, until...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This morning, my ex-wife caught me stealing money from her sock drawer. And it wasn’t the first time. Purple sock. Same one she kept her cash in when we were together. Gerry pauses for a response, but doesn’t get one.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not a good person, Curtis... I don’t deserve you. But it’s like you were sent to me. Like a leprechaun. A fucking handsome leprechaun dropped down in the middle of Iowa. And the reason I lost in Memphis is you weren’t there with me. I can’t do it alone. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 88 89 90 91 92 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 90.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're in this together. And I want you to know-- I didn’t follow you down this damn river to lose. HOLD ON CURTIS processing. After a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Long way down, ain’t it Gerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry's car exits the highway in New Orleans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 88 89 The PAWN BROKER examines Gerry’s items, punching numbers old adding machine. Gerry intently watches his small box possessions (wedding ring and all) being valued one by on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car SALESMAN counts out bills into Gerry’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis and Gerry make their way to the grandstand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry and Curtis look over the schedule and horses before next race.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: This is the horse. Number three, “Toto’s Revenge.”

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Seven to one. I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It’s Toto’s fucking Revenge.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I say we go with the favorite here. Number one.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Mississippi Grind?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Just feels right. 90 91 92  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 91.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It's Toto, Curtis! Dorothy! Rainbows! This is our pony. THIS feels right. This feels more than right.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You want to blow it all on a long shot.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I want to win it all on a long shot. Curtis looks at Gerry for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Okay. Toto’s Revenge.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: C'mon, Curtis, I need you to be with me on this.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m with you, I’m with you.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Are you feeling it?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (he isn’t) I'm feeling it.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No. I need you to really feel it. I‘1l ask you again-- is this our horse?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: This is our horse.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Is this our horse, Curtis?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: This is our horse, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Say it again.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Toto’s Revenge is our horse.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Curtis takes a few steps away towards the betting window, Gerry watches him.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 92.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDSTAND
dialogues.text: They both sit down in the sparsely populated seating area Gerry anxiously bites his lip, as the horses step into th starting gate.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: She’s a winner. I can feel it. Curtis nods. A bell sounds and the horses fly out of the

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C’mon three! Curtis remains silent, as the horses pull into the first

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: And it’s Toto’s Revenge breaking out into the lead with Sweet Feet and Mississippi Grind on the outside.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hot damn! C’mon Toto! Gerry leaps to his feet, while Curtis stares straight ahe unable to watch.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Toto’s Revenge loses steam with Sweet Feet moving into the front of the pack. And here comes Mississippi Grind on the outside!

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No! C’mon Toto! Damnit, c’mon you stupid horse!

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Mississippi Grind and Sweet Feet are neck and neck--

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Run! Run! Don’t stop! The horses cross the finish line.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: And it’s Mississippi Grind at the finish line! Gerry and Curtis both stare at the track in shock. Gerry believe it. He lowers his head, closes his eyes.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 93.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It had to end like this, Gerry. Here’s a hundred bucks. Get yourself a bus ticket and go home. Gerry perks up.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You didn’t bet it all?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I saved us a hundred each. Just in case.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: So we have two hundred.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: No. You have one hundred. I have one hundred. Gerry fumbles through the schedule, looking at the lineup the next race.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Thunder Clap!

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Stop it, Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Forty to one. We lay the two hundred and we're back in business.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: We're done.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What about Tony Roundtree? My white suit? We can still make it.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It’s over Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: But we’re so close.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It was a fantasy.  94

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: We just need to believe--

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It was never going to happen for us, Gerry. Beat. Gerry looks Curtis over, as if searching for a tell he find it?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: So that’s that.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Thanks for the ride. I’m sorry it didn’t work out. Gerry nods. He gives a false smile and heads for the exit We HOLD on Curtis for an extended beat, until he finally up, slowly strolls to the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis calmly steps up to the teller, hands her his ticke She processes the ticket, then proceeds to count out a la of cash. Curtis stares at it without emotion. The teller loads a stack of $100 bills into an envelope. takes the envelope and turns around to find... ...Gerry. Standing a few feet back. Watching him. The two stare at each other for an extended beat, then...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I thought you didn’t care about the money.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Then, why?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It’s not fun watching you lose. Gerry looks away, unsure what to say. Then...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: How’d you know it was Mississippi Grind?  95 96 97 98 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 95.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: He was the favorite.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: But how’d you know?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I didn't. It’s not magic, Gerry. Curtis lets this land, then hands over the envelope of ca

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here, take it. Gerry stares at the money, but shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I'd just blow it anyway, right? He walks away, leaving Curtis with the cash in his hand. ON Curtis, watching Gerry go.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. STREETCAR
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Gerry staring out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis strolls down the street in a rougher part of town cigarette hanging between his lips. He gets strange looks the LOCALS as he swigs from a flask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry dials 4-1-1 and an operator answers.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: New Orleans, Louisiana... Last name Roundtree. First name Tony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dimly lit court, where a two-on-two basketball game is place among some rough and tumble LOCALS. Curtis approach court.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You fellas know where a guy can shoot some darts around here? The tough-looking players stop their game and size Curtis  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 96.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l play your best guy for a hundred bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab pulls away, leaving Gerry standing in front of an o single-story house, dwarfed beneath a lit-up bridge. Less glamorous. He checks the address in his hand. This is not he imagined Tony Roundtree’s home. Gerry cautiously approaches the front door. Knocks. He lo both ways down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis is doing his best, but he is extremely overmatched opponent, who dunks over him. 101 EXT. TONY ROUNDTREE’S HOUSE 101 A disheveled man (late 60s) opens the door. An e-cigarett between his lips. He is TONY ROUNDTREE. He stares blankly Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Tony? Tony Roundtree? Tony sizes Gerry up, says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m Gerry. You don’t know me, but I’m a friend of Curtis. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Curtis Vonn. Tony sucks on his e-cig. His silence is unnerving.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is there a poker game here tonight? Still nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you the Tony Roundtree I’m looking for? You met Curtis on an Amtrak train to Albuquerque? (suddenly uncertain, even as he says it...) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He said you were wearing a Blue Velvet smoking jacket and traveling with a tiger you won from an Arab prince? Tony stares at Gerry. The ultimate poker face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis’ opponent hits a fade-away jump-shot.

dialogues.speaker: BALLER
dialogues.text: That’s game... Hundred bucks. Curtis stares at the guy, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: BALLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Something funny?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I don’t have it.

dialogues.speaker: BALLER
dialogues.text: You don’t have the money? Curtis shrugs as the other players converge onto the cour surrounding him.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What’re you gonna do about it? And WHACK! He is immediately punched in the face. Falls d 103 EXT. TONY ROUNDTREE’S HOUSE 103 Gerry pleads with Tony.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You lived in Detroit, right? That's where you became a disassociated person who couldn’t collect on a bad beat jackpot. Please, tell me you know what I'm talking about. There can't be two Tony Roundtrees in New Orleans. A long, excruciating beat. Then finally...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You know Curtis?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes, I know Curtis. He’s a friend. A close, personal friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony continues to look Gerry over.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you hosting a poker game here tonight?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Curtis with you?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: No. He couldn’t make it. But he wanted me to let you know that you should let me in.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Let you in?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Okay, full disclosure-- I’m a little short on the buy-in. I’ma little short. But you seem like a reasonable guy and I’m willing to bet we can work something out. You know what I mean? Some kind of financial agreement-- like say sixty/forty... or seventy/thirty? 98. There is a long awkward pause between them. Tony starts t laugh. So Gerry does the same. Both men are laughing, the

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What’s your name, man?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: And you say Curtis is a close friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Yes! Very close. Extremely close. We go back-- oh, I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Gerry, can you give Curtis a message for me? Before Gerry has time to respond-- WHACK! Tony socks Gerry in the face. Gerry stumbles back. before he knows what hit him, Tony goes inside, SLAMMING DOOR behind him. HOLD ON Gerry rubbing his jaw.  104 105 106 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis’ nose is swollen and bleeding. His opponent hovers him, grabs him by the collar, and digs into his jacket po He comes up empty, then digs into the other pocket.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Bingo. The baller’s hand comes out of Curtis’ coat with the enve

dialogues.speaker: BALLER
dialogues.text: (seeing the cash) What’s wrong with you, man?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I had it coming.

dialogues.speaker: BALLER
dialogues.text: There’s like five grand in here.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: So take it.

dialogues.speaker: BALLER
dialogues.text: You're a crazy son of a bitch, you know that? The baller peels off two hundred dollar bills, pockets th tucks the envelope back in Curtis’ jacket. He and his fri leave the court, shaking their heads. Curtis stands up, dusts himself off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN off of a receding streetcar onto Gerry looking off-sc We follow him as he approaches the downtown New Orleans c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLDER WOMAN, life experience etched on her face, sings plays the piano in the corner with a three-piece band. Th patrons chat quietly and listen to the music. No tourists sight-- this place is a far cry from the French Quarter. Curtis pauses as he steps through the door, watches the j singer for an extended beat before making his way to the Curtis sits down and the bartender (PETE, 50s) seems to recognize him. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: It’s been too long, man. How ya been?  107 108 109 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 100.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Livin’ the dream.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What happened to your face?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You should see the other guy’s hand. Gimme a bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What kind?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Cheap stuff. The bartender pours some cheap shot of bourbon for Curtis continues to watch and listen to the woman performing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry strolls past the slots, but stops upon seeing a bed slot machine with a blinking rainbow theme. He thinks for beat, then digs into his pocket for a quarter. He deposits it into the machine, pushes the spin button, reels start spinning... one, two, three, they come to a s with no winning combination. The rainbow magic is gone. G thinks for a beat, then walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jazz singer finishes her set to mellow applause and s off the stage. She notices Curtis and approaches the bar, the bartender has a mint julep waiting for her. Curtis sm

dialogues.speaker: SINGER
dialogues.text: Thanks, Pete. You got my smokes? Pete, the bartender, passes her a handbag from behind the and she takes out a pack of cigarettes. Curtis lights her

dialogues.speaker: SINGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks darlin’.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Happy birthday, mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a roulette wheel spinning. We TILT up to reveal watching a few steps away from the table.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 101. Gerry steps up, lays down his $100 bill. He takes a seat croupier changes his bill, handing him a stack of chips. Gerry places ALL OF HIS CHIPS onto the “double zero” squa 37-1 odds, one of the least probable bets on a roulette t Then steps back and nods to himself, resigned to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis’ mom, CHERRY VONN, sits down beside him. Years of smoking and drinking and crooning have taken their toll o Cherry's voice, which is rough and tough.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: A little late, aren’t ya?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Just a day or two.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: Was beginning to think you might not make it this year. Where ya been hiding, baby?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Not hiding... traveling.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh... travelers have a destination, honey.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: The journey is the--

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: --journey is the destination? She rolls her eyes. This woman has zero tolerance for bul

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, it’s good to see you, anyway. You bring me anything?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Didn’t have time to stop.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: I know the feeling... Cherry points out a missing button on Curtis’s shirt-- a of his earlier scuffle.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You lost a button, baby.  112 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 102.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Will you sew me a new one?

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: You came alone?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: All by myself.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: You should find somebody. A man alone is half a man.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I think I’m doin’ all right.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh... Cherry takes a long drag on her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen, baby, this year’s been unkind to your mama... Curtis smiles like he knew this was coming.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: How much do you need? Cherry shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: It don’t really matter. Life’s a long grind, ain’t it? I gotta get back to work, darlin’... Stick around for the next set, I’1l buy you a drink. She gives Curtis a wink as she slides her handbag toward and saunters back to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The croupier spins the wheel and drops the ball in. We sl ZOOM IN on the ball spinning around the wheel. Gerry watches without emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cherry begins to perform again on stage. Curtis watches h a beat, then reaches into his envelope, takes out a singl bill. He folds it, keeps it for himself, then slides the across the bar to Pete.  113 114 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 103.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Make sure she gets this.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This one’s for my little boy over there... Pete nods, stashes it safely behind the bar. Curtis turns to the stage, listens to his mother sing. Slow and haunti Cherry sings a cover of an old song about RAINBOWS. Curtis smiles. (There’s only one person could truly appre the serendipity of this moment.) With purpose, he stands exits as Cherry’s singing carries over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON the little white ball spinning round and round.. takes a deep breath, ready to start life again with absol nothing. CLICK. The ball drops into the “double zero” slot and the group of onlookers ERUPT. Gerry stares at the ball, as onlookers cheer and slap him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Curtis pacing down the middle of the street as tourists pass in and out of frame. Cherry's rendition of “The Rainbow Song” ends to mild app

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry sits alone at a $100 minimum bet Blackjack table. H a hefty stack of chips in front of him, and he’s playing bets on multiple hands... And he’s winning. Someone steps into frame and lays $100 on the table. Gerr looks up, watches as the new player takes a seat. The dea passes a single $100 chip to the man, and we discover... ...the new player is Curtis. Curtis and Gerry check each other out silently, both noti the other's new bruises. But they don't acknowledge each Curtis places his only chip in the betting circle. Gerry pushes a stack of chips in each of his three bettin circles.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 104. The dealer dishes out the cards, and Gerry waves his hand sticking with his dealt cards on all three hands. Curtis taps the table, and the dealer flips over another Queen. Curtis busts and the dealer collects his only chip Curtis watches as the dealer also busts. Curtis nods to Gerry as he stands to go, when Gerry tosse another chip. Curtis smiles thanks to Gerry and retakes h seat. For the next hand, Curtis bets his single chip again, whi Gerry lets the winnings from the previous hands ride. The hands are dealt. This time, both Gerry and Curtis sti with their cards. The dealer busts with a king. He passes single chip to Curtis and doubles Gerry’s giant stacks. C tosses the borrowed chip back to Gerry. Gerry smiles as a waitress steps up to the table.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Two Woodfords. Another hand is dealt. They both win. A rapid-fire series of cuts propel us through several mor hands. Curtis manages to double his winnings with each ha So does Gerry. They are on fire. A small group of onlooke has gathered around their table. They cheer with every wi As the waitress arrives with their Woodfords...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (indicating Curtis's broken nose) I was planning to give you a message from Tony Roundtree... but looks like you already got it.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (bewildered) You saw Tony?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: He was just like you described him. Curtis shoots him a sly grin. The two men raise their gla and...

dialogues.speaker: THE CRAPS TABLE
dialogues.text: We PUSH IN on Gerry and Curtis SCREAMING after a roll of dice. They are men possessed. Chips coming out of their e  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 105. Gerry rolls again. Another ERUPTION. The atmosphere is in It feels like half the casino is gathered around their ta Gerry is visibly manic with conflicting emotions. Giddy w joy one moment, spooked with fear the next. (In many ways is his worst nightmare. Is he capable of walking away fro streak of a lifetime?) Curtis’ phone RINGS and he checks the incoming...

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: It’s Simone! I have to take it.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You can’t leave!

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I'll be right here. I’m not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Make it quick. Curtis takes one step away from the table, while Gerry co to win behind him.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Do you hear this? That is the sweet sound of success! Pack your bags tonight! We did it!... I don’t know where we're going, but we want you there with us. Vegas, Monte Carlo, fucking Salt Lake City, I don’t give a shit! Hello? (pause) I’m sorry it’s loud. I just wanted to tell you... I love you! (beat) Did you hear me? I LOVE YOU! Okay, okay. Call me tomorrow! Curtis hangs up, rejoins Gerry at THE CRAPS TABLE.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: We can’t lose.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: We can’t lose. They smile at each other. A long beat. Gerry surveys his surroundings. Smiling faces, stacks of chips, blinking li  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 106.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: One last roll. All or nothing. Curtis stares at Gerry. Is he serious?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m serious.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Wait, Gerry, hang on a sec.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It’s okay. We can’t lose.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: We can’t lose.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: We can’t lose. Beat. There’s a strange tranquility between them.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: We made it.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: We made it.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I’m not afraid. Gerry pushes their mountain of chips towards the betting

dialogues.speaker: CROUPIER
dialogues.text: Everything? Gerry nods. The croupier hesitates, then calls over a MAN to approve the massive bet. The manager watches with a si crowd as the croupier stacks the chips into piles... fift thousand, hundred thousand, one fifty, up and up until... CROUPIER (CONT’D) Two hundred eighty five thousand. The manager looks at Gerry and Curtis, who are patiently waiting. He speaks into a walkie talkie, then finally... ..-nods his approval. CROUPIER (CONT’D) Your roll. The crowd around the table remains tense as Gerry holds t up for Curtis, who gives them a blow.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 107. Gerry shakes the dice in his hand... and let’s them fly. We rapidly PUSH IN on their faces as Curtis and Gerry bot forward in anticipation--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis and Gerry sit across from each other in a restaura overlooking the casino floor. They are both emotionally d We PULL BACK to reveal a table filled with champagne, ste lobster.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I love this country.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (still processing) I just bet two hundred eighty five grand on a roll of the dice.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: A hero is nothing more than the guy who pulls off what the rest of us are scared to do. I was wrong about you. I thought you were a sick pony that I was going to have to put down. But you're a hero, Gerry. A new American legend. Gerry takes a few bites. Chews. Something isn’t right.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Try it. Curtis samples a bite of Gerry’s steak. Curtis melts.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Oh my god...

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: See?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: That is delicious.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: You can’t taste it? Something’s off.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 108.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: There is nothing off about this steak, Gerry. Gerry looks around, calls for the waitress.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Excuse me!

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Gerry--

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Could I get a cheeseburger?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, is there something wrong with your steak?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: No, don’t worry, it’s perfect. I'll eat it.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Okay. I’11 be back with that burger. An awkward beat.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: It has a funny taste.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: What’s the matter? You should be walking on sunshine right now.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I am. I’m walking on sunshine.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: And don’t it feel good? Here, try some lobster. Gerry declines the bite.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gerry, you just won half a million dollars. Cheer the fuck up... Tell you what I’m gonna do. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 109.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First thing tomorrow, I’m gonna head over to the Cadillac man and buy me a shiny new white Caddy. What do you want, Gerry? You want a new Cadillac?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After you pay off your debts. Your ex wife. Tell me what you want. What you really really want. Could be anything. First thing you think of. Hit me, Gerry. What do you want? One, two, three lay it on me! Gerry! What do you want? We sit with Gerry, uncertain, wondering if his wildest dr come true might also be his worst nightmare. Now he must the responsibilities he’s had an excuse to avoid all this Beat.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I want to do something nice for Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Great! Who’s Wendy?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: My daughter.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Your daughter? Holy shit, man! You never said you had a kid!

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (genuinely surprised) I didn’t?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: No. But that’s great. How old is she?

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Um... Seven? No, six. Six. I think.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: You think? They both look off for an introspective beat. Hold on a W these two bruised and beaten winners.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: She's six.  120 121 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 110.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: So there you have it. Tomorrow's a new day. And so’s the next.

dialogues.speaker: V.I.P. SUITE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Gerry stares out the giant windows at the sun rising over Mississippi. He is freshly showered, wearing a towel arou waist. A new bandage covers his stomach wound.

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES LATER 119
dialogues.text: Gerry kneels in front of the safe. He punches in the code opens the door. The safe is completely filled with neatly stacked piles of mint $100 bills-- roughly half a million Gerry stares at all the cash...

dialogues.speaker: V.I.P. SUITE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: A RINGING cell phone stirs Curtis awake. Curtis reaches f his phone, sees Simone’s name. He thinks for a beat, torm but... .--he declines the call. He stares at the ceiling, and WE REVEAL A NAKED WOMAN as rolls over in bed beside him. He sits up on the edge of the bed, rubs his head.

dialogues.speaker: V.I.P. SUITE LIVING ROOM 121
dialogues.text: Curtis wanders into the living room, calling into the adj bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I had a dream we were on a steamboat. And river bandits stole our money. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gerry? Curtis looks into the adjoining room. It’s empty. He leans back against the wall, thinking. After a beat, Curtis goes to the safe. He punches in a fo digit code and opens the safe to find...  122 123 124 125 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 111. .-.it is half-filled with cash. There is a handwritten no where Gerry’s half used to be: “It’s machu picchu time. G hell, you beautiful loser!” Curtis smiles, bittersweet.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Machu Picchu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis approaches the front desk, his bag in hand.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I'd like to check out of my V.I.P. penthouse suite... Alice. He hands the cute receptionist, ALICE, his key. She smile types on her computer.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Looks like everything’s been comped, Mr. Vonn. How was your trip?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: My trip was spectacular, thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You heading home today? Curtis thinks for a beat, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Peru. I’m off to Peru.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Peru? Wow. That sounds nice.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Wanta come with me? She smiles, blushes.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve never been more serious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry reaches into a bag, full of cash, grabbing a roll o bills.  OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 111A. He counts out hundreds to the same used car salesman who his car yesterday. Gerry notices the salesman looking at cash.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: I got lucky.  126 OFFICIAL YELLOW 3/3/14 112.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAR 126
dialogues.text: Gerry climbs in. Sits. With his bandaged hand, he reaches his pocket, removes the partially bloodied photo of Wendy his cat. (Is he ready to face what he’s been running from these years?) He clips the photo to the visor above his h And starts the ignition. Joe Navarro’s “200 Poker Tells” immediately. JOE NAVARRO’S VOICE Number one hundred twenty: Relaxed and Squared. Shoulders that are suddenly relaxed and squared are saying, “I am confident.” If someone goes from slumped shoulders to squared relaxed shoulders I would be concerned as they are likely to be strong. Gerry, slumped back in his seat, straightens up, squares shoulders. He looks at himself in the rearview mirror. He scrunches his face. Then relaxes. CUT TO BLACK.
